title: Browns' Quinshon Judkins won't be charged, per Broward State Attorney's Office
description: Prosecutors declined battery charges for Quinshon Judkins following his July arrest, according to the Broward County State Attorney's Office.
content:
• The Broward County State Attorney’s Office cited lack of video evidence, independent witnesses, and a delayed report as reasons for not pursuing the case.
• The NFL is reviewing the matter and Judkins remains unsigned and unable to participate in training camp.

Quinshon Judkins remains the last unsigned player from the 2025 NFL Draft class, but that may not be the case for much longer.

On Thursday, the Broward County State Attorney's Office announced they have declined to move forward with a misdemeanor battery charge in the case against the Cleveland Browns' rookie running back.

Judkins was arrested in Fort Lauderdale, Florida on July 12 where he faced a single charge under Florida statute 784.03, relating to "touch or strike/battery/domestic violence."

Barbara M. Driscoll, Assistant State Attorney Domestic Violence Unit, outlined the reasons the prosecution decided against moving forward with the case:
• "This incident was not captured on any video surveillance."
• "There are no independent witnesses to the incident."
• "Although the victim had photos showing injuries sustained, there were also videos in that same time frame where no injuries were observed to the victim."
• "Additionally, the victim's injuries depicted in the photos could be explained by either account of the incident."
• "Finally, there was a delayed report of the incident. The delay is problematic as the victim was alone on numerous occasions without the Defendant, had the ability and resources to make the report without his knowledge, but chose not to do so."

Driscoll said there is "no reasonable likelihood of conviction" and that "the case is being declined."

The NFL stated to the Akron Beacon Journal (part of the USA TODAY Network), “We have been following developments in the matter which remains under review.”

The Browns drafted the former Ohio State and Ole Miss running back with the 36th pick in the 2025 NFL Draft. Judkins cannot participate in training camp until his contract is signed.

keywords.name: Assistant State Attorney Domestic Violence Unit

summary: The Broward County State Attorney's Office has declined to proceed with a misdemeanor battery charge against Cleveland Browns' rookie running back, Quinshon Judkins. The office cited lack of video evidence, independent witnesses, and a delayed report as reasons for not pursuing the case. Judkins remains unsigned and cannot participate in training camp until his contract is signed.
shortSummary: Clevelet's Quinshon Judkins won't face a battery charge due to lack of video evidence and a delayed report, while the NFL reviews the matter.

Broward County State Attorney's Office declines to charge Browns rookie Quinshon Judkins
This story has been updated with new information.
PHILADELPHIA — The Broward County State Attorney's Office will not be filing formal charges against Cleveland Browns running back Quinshon Judkins.
Barbara M. Driscoll, Assistant State Attorney Domestic Violence Unit, submitted a Decline Memorandum into Judkins' file with the Broward County State Attorney's Office on Aug. 14. In the memorandum, she stated multiple reasons for coming to the ultimate conclusion that "this is no reasonable likelihood of conviction" and that "this case is being declined."
The report stated the following reasons for the decision:
- "This incident was not captured on any video surveillance."
- "There are no independent witnesses to the incident."
- "Although the victim had photos showing injuries sustained, there were also videos in that same time frame where no injuries were observed to the victim."
- "Additionally, the victim's injuries depicted in the photos could be explained by either account of the incident."
- "Finally, there was a delayed report of the incident. The delay is problematic as the victim was alone on numerous occasions without the Defendant, had the ability and resources to make the report without his knowledge, but chose not to do so."
The memorandum that the Assistant State Attorney received "police reports, bodyworn camera videos, video surveillance from numerous places the couple has been, photos, phone records, and the victim's sworn statement." The memo said "the following evidence in the case was reviewed: body worn camera videos, surveillance videos from the airport, hotels, restaurants, clubs, and valet, photos showing bruising and marks on the victim, cell phone text messages and calls."
The memorandum stated the ASA was in contact with Judkins' attorney, who submitted a proffer of Judkins' version of the events. The ASA and the State Attorney's Office's Victim Advocate were also in frequent contact with the victim, who had retained her own attorney.
The Browns did not have a comment. The NFL issued a statement to the Beacon Journal saying, "We have been following developments in the matter which remains under review.”
Judkins' original arrest by Fort Lauderdale police brought with it a charge of "touch or strike/battery/domestic violence," which is a first-degree misdemeanor in Florida. However, the 175-day waiver in the filing would cover a felony charge, while a misdemeanor would only be a 60-day window.
The filing is the first of any kind in Judkins' case since he was released on a $2,500 bond on July 13, a day after his arrest. There had been no hearings of any kind set by the court system since then.
Judkins' arrest stemmed from an incident on July 7 when the woman with whom he was traveling told police he "punched her in the mouth/chin area with a closed fist." He later allegedly punched her on her left arm and leg while in their rental car.
Judkins, taking No. 36 overall, is the only pick from the 2025 NFL Draft who remains unsigned. The Browns tabled their contract negotiations with the former Ohio State and Ole Miss running back while the legal process played out.
Unsigned draft picks can not participate in training camp. They are not subjected to fines for missed time.
Chris Easterling can be reached at ceasterling@thebeaconjournal.com. Read more about the Browns at www.beaconjournal.com/sports/browns. Follow him on X at @ceasterlingABJ

Browns rookie RB Quinshon Judkins arrested on battery charge in Florida
Cleveland Browns rookie running back Quinshon Judkins was arrested in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on Saturday, July 12.
According to the arrest report from the Broward County Sheriff's Office, Judkins was arrested and faces a single charge under Florida statute 784.03, relating to "touch or strike/battery/domestic violence." There is no bond amount set for Judkins, and his charge status is pending trial, according to police records.
Per the Florida criminal code, Judkins faces a charge of battery, in which a person "actually and intentionally touches or strikes another person against the will of the other" — typically a first-degree misdemeanor that carries a penalty of a "definite term of imprisonment not exceeding one year" and a $1,000 fine.
Selected with the 36th overall pick in the second round of the 2025 NFL Draft by the Browns, Judkins was one of 14 Ohio State players drafted back in April.
A Browns spokesperson told the Akron Beacon Journal, part of the USA TODAY Network, that the team was "aware and gathering information" about Judkins' arrest.
Adam Schefter reported July 13 the NFL is “aware of the matter but will decline further comment" as well.
ESPN's Daniel Oyefusi also reported details of the arrest passed along by Police Department Media Relations in Fort Lauderdale, saying: “On July 12th, at approximately 9 a.m., Fort Lauderdale Police Officers responded to the 1500 block of West Cypress Creek Road in reference to a delayed battery. Officers arrived on scene and spoke with the victim. During their preliminary investigation it was determined a battery had occurred. The officers made contact with the suspect and placed him into custody. He was transported to Broward County Main Jail. The suspect has been identified as Quinshon Judkins, DOB 10/29/2003 and has been charged with Misdemeanor Battery (Domestic) FSS 784.03-1a1.”
On July 14, NFL Network's Tom Pelissero reported additional information from the police report that Judkins' accuser told police that "he punched her with a closed fist in the chin/lip area and later struck her in the left arm and thigh while they were in the car when leaving the airport on July 7."
In his lone season at Ohio State, Judkins was part of a one-two punch running back group with TreVeyon Henderson, helping lead the Buckeyes to their first College Football Playoff national championship since 2014 with a 34-23 win over Notre Dame.
In 16 games this past season for the Buckeyes, Judkins ran for 1,060 yards and 14 rushing touchdowns on 194 carries, adding 161 receiving yards and two receiving touchdowns on 22 receptions. He ran for 100 yards and two touchdowns in the national championship game.
Across his three seasons at Ole Miss and Ohio State, Judkins ran for a combined 3,785 yards and 45 touchdowns. Judkins is scheduled to report to his first NFL training camp on Friday, July 18 with the rest of the Browns' rookies, per NFL.com.
This story has been republished with new information.

argos_summary: The Broward County State Attorney's Office has decided not to pursue misdemeanor battery charges against Cleveland Browns rookie running back Quinshon Judkins, citing a lack of video evidence, independent witnesses, and a delayed report from the victim. Judkins was arrested on July 12 for allegedly striking a woman during an incident on July 7, but the Assistant State Attorney concluded there was no reasonable likelihood of conviction. As a result, Judkins remains unsigned and unable to participate in training camp while the NFL continues to review the situation.
